summary: This is a letter from the U.S. Department of Justice, Office of the Deputy Attorney General, to attorneys Jay Lefkowitz and Kenneth Starr regarding the DOJ's review of the U.S. Attorney's handling of the Jeffrey Epstein case. The letter states that after a thorough review, the DOJ finds no reason to intervene or alter the U.S. Attorney's approach, and believes federal prosecution is appropriate. It also addresses and dismisses allegations of prosecutorial misconduct.

persons.name: Jay Lefkowitz
persons.context: Attorney representing Jeffrey Epstein, recipient of this DOJ letter along with Kenneth Starr.

persons.context: Attorney representing Jeffrey Epstein, recipient of this DOJ letter along with Jay Lefkowitz.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The client of attorneys Lefkowitz and Starr; the subject of the DOJ's review regarding the U.S. Attorney's handling of his case.

persons.name: Alex Acosta
persons.context: U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of Florida; copied on this letter regarding the handling of the Epstein matter.

connections.description: Lefkowitz is an attorney representing Epstein, as indicated by the letter being addressed to him and Kenneth Starr regarding 'your client, Jeffrey Epstein.'
Starr is an attorney representing Epstein, as indicated by the letter being addressed to him and Jay Lefkowitz regarding 'your client, Jeffrey Epstein.'
Both are attorneys at Kirkland and Ellis LLP representing the same client, Jeffrey Epstein.
Acosta was the U.S. Attorney whose office's handling of the Epstein case is the subject of this DOJ review.

events.title: Defense Letter to DOJ
events.description: Epstein's defense attorneys submitted a letter to the Department of Justice regarding the handling of the case.

events.title: Defense Letter to DOJ
events.description: Epstein's defense attorneys submitted a second letter to the Department of Justice.

events.title: Defense Letter with Attachments
events.description: Epstein's defense attorneys submitted a third letter with attachments to the Department of Justice, likely containing allegations of prosecutorial misconduct.

events.title: DOJ Review Completion Letter
events.description: The DOJ's Office of the Deputy Attorney General sends a letter concluding its review of the U.S. Attorney's handling of the Epstein case, declining to intervene.

locations: 777 South Figueroa Street, Los Angeles, CA
keyFacts: The U.S. Department of Justice completed a review of the U.S. Attorney's handling of the Jeffrey Epstein case and decided not to intervene.
Epstein's defense attorneys (Lefkowitz and Starr) had submitted multiple letters alleging prosecutorial misconduct, which the DOJ reviewed and dismissed.
The DOJ stated that even if it substituted its judgment, it believed federal prosecution of Epstein was appropriate.
The Deputy Attorney General had been briefed on the matter, indicating high-level attention within the DOJ.
Alex Acosta, the U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of Florida, was copied on the letter, confirming his office's central role in the case handling under review.
